Lucy Dyke (m. 2017)}} | children = 5 | genre = [[Observational comedy]] | website = [http://www.jasonmanford.com/ Official website] }} '''Jason John Manford'''[http://www.sundaymercury.net/entertainment-news/tv-news/2010/08/15/7-things-you-never-knew-about-jason-manford-66331-27059275/ 7 things you never knew about Jason Manford] Sunday Mercury, 15 August 2010 (born 26 May 1981) is an English comedian, television presenter and radio presenter, best known for being a team captain on the [[Channel 4]] panel show ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]'' from 2007 until 2010. He has presented numerous television shows for the [[BBC]] and [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] including ''Comedy Rocks'' (2010–2011), ''[[The One Show]]'' (2010), ''[[Show Me the Funny]]'' (2011), ''[[A Question of Sport: Super Saturday]]'' (2014) and ''[[Bigheads]]'' (2017). ==Early life== Manford was born[https://www.mirror.co.uk/tv-entertainment/most-popular/2010/05/29/meet-jason-manford-he-s-the-one-to-make-christine-bleakley-laugh-115875-22293735 Meet Jason Manford – he's The One to make Christine Bleakley laugh] Mirror, 29 May 2010 in [[City of Salford|Salford]], [[Greater Manchester]]. His mother, Sharon (née Ryan), is of Irish Catholic extraction, her mother, Nora (née Peate), having been born in Dublin.Jason Manford, ''Brung Up Proper: My Autobiography'' (2012), p. 23Interview, ''[[The Graham Norton Show]], 28 June 2010. His father, Ian Manford, is a courtroom [[stenographer]]. Jason and his four siblings grew up in a [[terraced house]] in what is known as the [[Gun crime in south Manchester|"Triangle of Death"]] area of south [[Manchester]] notorious for its gang activity and high crime rate. {{cite news|title=This much I know: Jason Manford|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2011/nov/20/jason-manford-comedian-interview|publisher=[[The Guardian|guardian.co.uk]]|date=20 November 2011}} He attended Chorlton High School when it was known as Oakwood High School and formed a band with two of his school friends, Simon and Neil. His mother later said that this was what got him into singing. When Manford was seventeen, he got a job as a glass collector at a local pub.{{cite news|title=Jason Manford: How Peter Kay got me into Salford University|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/tv_and_showbiz/s/1459838_jason-manford-how-peter-kay-got-me-into-salford-university|publisher=[[Manchester Evening News]]|date=27 September 2011}} While working there, Manford became interested in comedy after watching the likes of [[Peter Kay]], [[Eddie Izzard]] and [[Johnny Vegas]] perform at the local comedy club. Kay recommended him to do the [[Higher National Diploma]] in media and performance at the [[University of Salford]].{{cite news|title=Jason Manford: Interview|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/comedy/features/6646/Jason_Manford-interview.html|publisher=[[Time Out (company)|Time Out]]|date=15 January 2009}} Despite not having the required [[A Levels|A Level]] grades, he was accepted into the programme and eventually upgraded to a full degree. Manford's brother, Colin, a [[University of Salford]] graduate, followed him into performing{{cite news|title=Colin Manford to follow in the footsteps of famous brother Jason|url=http://mancunianmatters.co.uk/content/12111680-colin-manford-follow-footsteps-famous-brother-jason|date=12 November 2011}} and is also a stand-up comedian, based in Manchester.[http://www.mancunianmatters.co.uk/content/300666028-stepping-out-his-brothers-shadow-colin-manford Shadow: Colin Manford], mancunianmatters.co.uk, 30 June 2010; retrieved 24 April 2014. ==Career== ===Television=== From June to November 2007, Manford was on ''Ideal'',{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p00905mg|title=BBC Three - Ideal, Series 1, The Boyfriend|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|date=1 October 2006|accessdate=26 April 2014}} where he had a small part as Jack, who had been dumped and cheated on by his girlfriend with 'little Darren', 'big Darren' and 'flu-strength Darren'. He later made another appearance in episode five of that series. He hosted a breakfast show on [[Xfm Manchester]][http://www.xfm.co.uk/onair/djs/jason-manford Jason Manford] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124103946/http://www.xfm.co.uk/onair/djs/jason-manford |date=24 January 2010 }} Xfm, 24 December 2006 until May 2008.[http://www.how-do.co.uk/north-west-media-news/north-west-broadcasting/mike-mcclean-to-take-over-from-jason-manford-at-xfm-200805062507/ Mike McClean to take over from Jason Manford at Xfm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080506182131/http://www.how-do.co.uk/north-west-media-news/north-west-broadcasting/mike-mcclean-to-take-over-from-jason-manford-at-xfm-200805062507/ |date=6 May 2008 }} How-Do, 6 May 2008 From June to November 2007, Manford was [[Paramount Comedy]]'s continuity announcer and writer.[http://www.comedy.co.uk/podcasts/richard_herring_edinburgh/ Comedy.co.uk] Richard Herring's Edinburgh fringe Podcast 26th Aug 2013 In June 2007, he took over from [[Dave Spikey]] as a team captain on ''[[8 Out of 10 Cats]]''.[https://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/05/21/jason-manford-10-things-you-need-to-know-about-the-english-comedian-writer-actor-and-television-presenter-115875-22273095/ Jason Manford: 10 things you need to know about the man tipped as the new One Show host], Mirror.co.uk, 21 May 2010. He presented his own show, ''[[Tonightly]]'', which aired every weekday from 1 to 22 August 2008 and appeared as a celebrity supporter for inventor Kin Kam in a special charity edition of [[BBC Two]]'s ''Dragons' Den'' for [[Sport Relief]].{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} In August 2009 Manford appeared for four episodes in [[Coronation Street]], playing hoover salesman, Percy Nozzle. Nozzle sat around in the Rovers just in shot and in one episode, enjoyed a game of [[darts]] with Keving Webster. Nozzle successfully sold one hoover to Roy, before moving to [[Emmerdale]] in search of more sales.{{cn|date=March 2018}} In September 2009, Manford appeared briefly in Emmerdale as Percy Nozzle, a hoover salesman, leaving Emmerdale after a disastrous Dyson demonstration caused minor damage to a picture of Mr Wilkes and Amos above the fireplace at the ''Woolpack'' that provoked outrage amongst the locals and no sales.{{cn|date=March 2018}} In March 2010, Manford was announced as host of a new comedy show called ''Comedy Rocks'', featuring stand up comedians and musical performances. A pilot was shown on ITV on 26 March 2010 and a full series began on the channel on 14 January 2011. On 26 May 2010, Manford was announced as the new presenter of [[BBC One]]'s ''[[The One Show]]'' from July 2010.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment_and_arts/10167068.stm|title=Comic Jason Manford named One Show host|work=BBC News|accessdate=26 May 2010|date=26 May 2010}} He resigned from the programme in November 2010 following allegations surrounding his private life.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11794466|title=Jason Manford quits The One Show|work=BBC News|date=19 November 2010}} He also made up one half of the Home Team with [[Peter Andre]] on the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] game show ''[[Odd One In]]''. In July 2011, Manford presented ''[[Show Me The Funny]]'', a reality show on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] involving 10 comedians in which one is voted off each week. In 2013, Manford hosted three pilots: ''Good News, Bad News'' and ''Oh! What a Week'' for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]], and ''You and Whose Army?'' for [[Sky1]]. None of them have yet been commissioned for a full series. He wrote and presented ''[[It's a Funny Old Week|A Funny Old Year]]'' which was broadcast on [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] on New Year's Eve in 2012, 2013 and 2014. The show saw Manford take a look back over the past year's humorous events.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Since 21 June 2014, Manford has hosted a [[BBC One]] show called ''[[A Question of Sport: Super Saturday]]'', a spin-off from [[BBC]] panel show ''[[A Question of Sport]]''.[http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/story/000001478/jason_manford_a_question_of_sport_super_saturday/ Comedy.co.uk] On 21 September 2014, Manford guest hosted an episode of ''[[Sunday Night at the Palladium]]''.[http://www.itv.com/presscentre/ep2week39/sunday-night-palladium ITV] He returned to present another show on 24 May 2015. Manford played the role of Marty in the 2015 BBC Drama ''[[Ordinary Lies]]''.[[Ordinary Lies]] In 2015, he hosted ''The Money Pit'' for [[Dave (TV channel)|Dave]] and ''[[It's a Funny Old Week]]'' for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].[http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/tv/news/a650311/jason-manford-will-host-a-new-topical-clip-show-on-itv.html#~pemxFzFkbvwSkI Digital Spy] In 2016, Manford joined [[Absolute Radio]] as their new Sunday morning show presenter. In April 2017, Manford guest presented five episodes of ''[[The Nightly Show (UK TV series)|The Nightly Show]]''. He also presented the ''[[2017 Laurence Olivier Awards]]'' for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]. In 2017, he presented a new Sunday-night entertainment series for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] called ''[[Bigheads]]''. In 2018, he will front ''What Would Your Kid Do?'', a new series for [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]].http://www.itv.com/presscentre/press-releases/what-would-your-kid-do-itv-announce-new-show-fronted-jason-manford ===Stand–up=== After a successful first UK tour{{cite web|title=Jason Manford 2008/09 tour|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/shows/tour/j/16020/jason_manford_2008_tour|publisher=Chortle|accessdate = 15 November 2008|date=September 2008}} and high sales of the following DVD, filmed live at the [[Manchester Apollo]], he started his "Turning Into My Dad" tour on 14 July 2010.[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/showbiz-and-lifestyle/showbiz/2010/03/16/jason-manford-rocks-the-comedy-circuit-91466-26042664/ Jason Manford rocks the comedy circuit] Wales Online, 16 March 2010. In March 2010, Manford took part in ''[[Channel 4's Comedy Gala (2010)|Channel 4's Comedy Gala]]'', a [[Benefit concert|benefit show]] held in aid of [[Great Ormond Street Hospital|Great Ormond Street Children's Hospital]], filmed live at the [[The O2 Arena (London)|O2 Arena]] in London on 30 March.{{Citation needed|date=June 2010}} He toured the UK with "First World Problems", between June and December 2013 and produced a DVD of the same name. His latest tour "Muddle Class" is currently touring across the UK, continuing until the end of 2018. [http://www.ents24.com/web/artist/31572/Jason_Manford.html Ents24.com] ===Acting=== In late 2013, Manford starred in the plusnet adverts as well as the voiceover artist for Jet2.com.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}and the [[voiceover]] on the [[Churchill Insurance]] adverts[https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/jason-manford-ive-always-been-240827 Jason Manford: "I’ve always been a smart arse. Now I’m a professional one"] Mirror, 15 August 2010 and is one of the voices in the BBC comedy sketch show ''[[Walk on the Wild Side (comedy show)|Walk on the Wild Side]]''. He appeared in series four of Channel 4's ''[[Shameless (UK TV series)|Shameless]]'' as a security guard who is seduced by [[List of Shameless characters#Karen Maguire|Karen Maguire]]. In July 2012, Manford took over the role of [[Adolfo Pirelli|Pirelli]] for a month (followed by a few dates in August) in the London revival of musical ''[[Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street#2012 London revival|Sweeney Todd]]'' at the [[Adelphi Theatre]] opposite [[Michael Ball (singer)|Michael Ball]] and [[Imelda Staunton]]. Manford has a minor voice role in the [[Xbox 360]] video game ''[[Fable III]]'', playing "Jammy" who teaches the player how to use mortars. Pvt. Jammy dies early in the game.[http://www.microsoft.com/games/mgsgamecatalog/fableIIIcredits.aspx Microsoft.com] He had a role in the [[BBC Three]] series ''[[Ideal (TV series)|Ideal]]'' and starred in an episode of [[BBC One]]'s ''[[Moving On (TV series)|Moving On]]''. In 2015, Manford played the role of Marty in the [[BBC One]] drama series ''[[Ordinary Lies]]'', starring alongside [[Michelle Keegan]], [[Max Beesley]] and [[Sally Lindsay]]. He also played the [[Mediumship|medium]] Alexander Le Cheyne in [[List of Ripper Street episodes#Series 3|Episode 3 of Series 3]] of ''[[Ripper Street]]''. In 2015, Manford starred in his second musical as Leo Bloom in the 2015 UK tour of [[Mel Brooks]]' ''[[The Producers (musical)|The Producers]]'' opposite [[Louie Spence]], [[Phill Jupitus]] and [[Ross Noble]]. He played [[Caractacus Potts]] in the UK tour of ''[[Chitty Chitty Bang Bang (musical)|Chitty Chitty Bang Bang]]'' alongside [[Phill Jupitus|Phil Jupitus]], [[Michelle Collins]], [[Martin Kemp]], [[Carrie Hope Fletcher]] and [[Claire Sweeney]]. He toured with the production from February to April 2016, before the role was played by [[Lee Mead]]. Manford returned to the role in October 2016 and continued until the end of the tour in February 2017. ====The Laugh Inn==== In 2011, Manford became one of the shareholders of the Chester-based comedy club The Laugh Inn. He frequented the club to see shows and support the circuit comedians as well as performing impromptu or unannounced shows. The club closed in 2013.http://www.thelaughinnchester.co.uk/ ===Singing=== Manford came from a family of singers and musicians and was regularly singing with them. In 2011 as part of filming the TV competition ''Born to Shine'' he was taught daily to sing in an Operatic style, he went on to win {{Cite web|url=http://www.chortle.co.uk/news/2011/08/21/13828/jason_manford_wins_born_to_shine#|title=Jason Manford wins Born To Shine : News 2011 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide|last=Solutions|first=Powder Blue Internet Business|website=www.chortle.co.uk|access-date=2017-09-18}} the show and has released an album of show tunes, called [[A Different Stage]]. ==Influences== Manford cites [[Billy Connolly]] as his comedy hero,{{cite web|url=http://www.list.co.uk/article/15164-jason-manford/|title=Jason Manford|accessdate=28 August 2009|publisher=The List}} after seeing him when Manford was 11, and comics such as [[Tommy Cooper]] and [[Peter Kay]] heavily influenced his comic style. In 2009, in an interview on ''[[Friday Night With Jonathan Ross]]'', Manford talked about his passion for musicals, expressing an interest in taking a singing and acting role on stage, and giving a short, impromptu performance of "Suddenly Seymour". ==Personal life== Manford married his first wife, Catherine, in October 2007. On 20 August 2009, she gave birth to healthy [[Twin#Dizygotic twins|twin]] daughters.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1326820/One-Shows-Jason-Manford-admits-sending-sexy-Twitter-messages-female-fan.html Married One Show host Jason Manford admits to sending sexy Twitter messages to female fan] Mail Online, 5 November 2010 His wife gave birth to their third daughter in December 2010, and a son in 2012.{{cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/life-style/life/537717/Jason-Manford-tour-The-One-Show-sex-text-scandal|work=express.co.uk|title=Jason Manford Tour}} The family lived in [[Stockport]], Greater Manchester.{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/tv_and_showbiz/s/1241861_one_show_spot_for_jason_manford |title=One Show spot for Jason Manford |work=Manchester Evening News |date=3 June 2010 |publisher=M.E.N. Media |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100606173845/http://menmedia.co.uk/tv_and_showbiz/s/1241861_one_show_spot_for_jason_manford |archivedate=6 June 2010 }} In May 2013, it was stated that they had split amicably.{{cite news|author=Fay Strang|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2318723/Jason-Manford-wife-time-6-year-marriage---amicably-broke-year.html|title=Jason Manford and wife call time on 6 year marriage... after they 'amicably' broke up last year|publisher=DailyMail|date=3 May 2013|accessdate=1 January 2014}} On 8 January 2015 at St Mary's Hospital in [[Manchester]], after 55 hours of labour, Manford's girlfriend, Lucy Dyke, gave birth to a daughter. Manford later revealed that they had donated the [[umbilical cord]] and the [[placenta]] for [[stem cell]] research and [[blood donation]]. On 18 November 2010, Manford resigned as co-host of ''[[The One Show]]'' "to concentrate on his family" following his admission to a number of allegations published in tabloid newspapers in regards to exchanging sexually-oriented [[Twitter]] messages with fans.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1331097/Jason-Manford-quits-The-One-Show-following-sex-message-claims.html Jason Manford quits The One Show to 'concentrate on his family' after sex message claims] Mail Online, 19 November 2010 Manford is a supporter of [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City FC]].{{cite web |title=Jason Manford's big 5 |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/Video/Features/Jason-Manford-Big-5|publisher=mcfc.co.uk|date=28 March 2010}} He is left-handed, and eats pies on a regular basis; where he even has a pie named after him at his local [[Greggs]]. He is also a close friend of comedian and actor, [[Steve Edge]]. ===Charity=== In November 2008, Manford became patron of Savebabies, a charity campaigning for newborn screening.[http://www.chesterchronicle.co.uk/entertainment-chester/chester-cinema-film-tv/2009/07/20/jason-manford-how-jason-became-the-man-59067-24196870/ Jason Manford: How Jason became the man] Chester Chronicle, 20 July 2009. Since April 2014, Manford has been supporting the [[cancer]] charity ''Stephen's Story''. [[Stephen Sutton]] was a nineteen-year-old terminally ill cancer patient who set up the initiative to help others battling the disease.{{cite web|author=Nicole Le Marie |url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/04/24/thumbsupforstephen-jason-manfords-2million-aim-for-stephen-sutton-fundraising-appeal-4707257/ |title=Stephen's Story: Jason Manford's £2m aim for Stephen Sutton fundraising appeal | Metro News |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-04-26}} All turnover from May 2014 at Manford's comedy clubs was given to Sutton's charity.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/permalink.php?story_fbid=10152084185769352&id=9212109351&stream_ref=10 |title=Jason Manford – I have a few comedy clubs dotted around... |publisher=Facebook |date= |accessdate=26 April 2014}} ==Awards== ;Won * Winner of the 1999 North West [[City Life Comedian of the Year]] * Winner of the 2000 [[Leicester Mercury Comedian of the Year]] * Winner of the 2005 Writers Guild of Great Britain and The List's Best Comedy Newcomer for his debut Edinburgh show Urban Legend * Winner 2006 [[Chortle]] Award for Best Breakthrough Act * Winner of the 2006 North West Comedy Awards category for Best Stand up on the North West Circuit ;Nominated * Finalist in the 2000 Channel Four [[So You Think You're Funny]] competition at the [[Edinburgh Fringe Festival]] * Nominated for the 2001 ''Manchester Evening News'' Theatre Award for Comedy * Nominated for the 2005 [[Perrier Award]] at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival for his debut one-man show Urban Legend ==Filmography== ;Television {| class="wikitable" |- !
